thig12.1:1.1: 'sīte' appears to be locative - perhaps locative of time. So I think it is referring to when the weather is cold, not the water that she is collecting. So perhaps this could be translated "I used to fetch water in the cold" or something similar. That said, considering the context of the rest of this sutta, it appears to me that 'udahārī' does not mean 'water-carrier' or 'one who fetches water', but rather someone who is devoted to the religious practice of bathing in cold water. The literal meaning of 'udahārī' is 'water-taker', but that may be similar to how we say things like "Now I will take a shower". So perhaps this line means "I am one who bathes in cold water..."
thig12.1:1.2: You left out the word 'sadā' - "always going into the water."
thig12.1:1.3: Bonus points for catching that 'ayyānaṁ' is masculine - not feminine as Bhante Sujāto misread it. Your translation appears to be correct.
thig12.1:3.1: 'vata' here appears to be the indeclinable exclamation indicating strong emotion (usually surprise or dismay), not the noun which means "religious observance" (if it was the noun, then it would be declined).
thig12.1:3.4: You left out 'kata' ("done") - the bad deeds that have been done. I might translate this line as "By making good karma, one obstructs the bad karma that was previously made." or maybe "By making good karma, one blocks past bad karma."
thig12.1:4.1: "One who does an evil deed, whether they are young or old, they are liberated from their bad karma through ritual bathing."
thig12.1:5.3: "Through ritual bathing one definitely is liberated from bad karma."
thig12.1:6.3: I think here 'nāga' has its meaning of 'water-dragon' rather than 'elephant', as in Buddhist cosmology dragons like to live in water, whereas elephants are land animals. So 'water-dragon' meaning fits better with the other water animals listed.
thig12.1:6.4: 'and any other being that travels in the water'. I might translate this sentence something like "Does this mean that all frogs, turtles, water-serpents, crocodiles, and all the other aquatic beings will go to heaven?"
thig12.1:7.1: No one says 'pork killers'. "Butchers of sheep and pigs" (or "Those who slaughter sheep and pigs" if you want to be less Suji-like.)
thig12.1:7.2: Suji is more correct here. "Miga-bandhaka" literally means "one who imprisons deer."
thig12.1:7.5: Nobody ever uses the word "ablution." Like, ever. "Ritual bathing" is okay, but not 'ablution'.
thig12.1:7.6: "would be liberated from their bad karma."
